body.p:
I am very thankful to you for your worthy letter of the 27th
of last month. The only think I regret is not to be able to give a more
satisfactory answer. According to my experiences, you are about to give
up your undertakings which you have cinducted for a long time with love,
commendable zeal, and success. What you are about to begin to do has
its bad side. Jewish interests are too dear to the heart of such as we
to be given up after half a lifetime of labor for them. If you were to
turn to political or other matters of the day, you may be successful.
You are perhaps particularly capable to edit a mixed newspaper in Eng-
lish and German, such as I have at one time hoped for and thought about.
But in doing so you will have to undergo new and bigger struggles. If
you were to turn to a completely new business you may have good success,
at the same time feel a void which for you especially, a man without a
family, can never fill with any kind of financial success. I have not
received your circular and have read it only in the “Shebat” number (March)
of the “Occident”. I went with it and with your letter to Mr. Nathan
Abeles. I asked him whether he could not do something in the matter,
since I myself am in touch with very few people, and these German Jews.
I told him that I would sign immediately after him if he were to open a
subscription list. He, too, however, explained to me that he does not
come in touch with any more and can do nothing in this matter. He will
speak to the brothers Shloss (Moses Shloss of Albany). Mr. Lach is but
little in St. Louis. He passed through. As soon as he (Abeles) will see
him next, he will tell him that he must be sure to come to me and I shall
talk with him on your behalf. If you want to know my opinion, I believe
that you should not turn the “Occident” into a monthly and a weekly, but
try to turn the monthly into a weekly which may procure 200 new subscri-

bers for the newspaper and no more. Should you make the attempt, please
send me per post a circular and prospectus, and I shall myself procure
for you several subscribers and send you the cash. The copy of Mr.
Michael de Young could not be found in the post office. You yourself
should have thrown it among the thrash as soon as you learned of
their unwillingness to receive it. Others of the numbers that I missed
I found in the letter-box of Messrs. Abeles and Taussig, in which I
find my mail. You again receive herewith an order of Mr. Petschau, for
the sending of several books, out of my commission book shop. These
are the books you seem to need. I beg of you in my own and in your in-
terest, to take a hand in my claims upon de Young in New York and to
let me know what is advisable and what is possible to be done.
